medium: Red chalk on light tan laid paper
creditline: Gift of Frank Jewett Mather Jr.
inscribed: Inscribed verso, lower right, in brown ink: n 23[9?]

texts.textentryhtml:
Unidentified stamp (six-pointed star, L. 2888?) recto, upper left, in black; Jerome Lanier, stamp recto, upper left, in black; Jonathan Richardson Sr., stamp (L. 2183) recto, lower right, in black; Duke of Rutland (according to note on old mat); Frank Jewett Mather Jr.;

From Gnann, “Parmigianino…”: Dates drawing ca. 1523-24 (early Parma period). (See reference Bib. 4621);

From Papham, “Catalogue of the drawings of Parmigianino”: Pre-Roman, ca. 1524. (See reference Bib. 4620);

From Scholz: “Italian drawings…”: “delicious”…a welcome addition to his oeuvre…early work.” (See reference Bib. 4382);

Formerly attributed to Pordenone, but recognized as a work by Parmigianino in the 1960s, this double-sided sheet exemplifies the rough, atmospheric lyricism of his early red chalk drawings, inspired by those of Correggio, then the leading artist in Parma. The lush outdoor setting, inhabited by a nude youth and two goats, is steeped in the pastoral tradition of Venetian art, as evoked most famously in Giorgione’s landscapes. The ultimate meaning of this seductive scene, which may have a Classical literary source, remains elusive.
